children.value: In the following definition we allow the velocity

children.html: ccc

children.value: to be specified as a parameter.
The following initial condition isn’t mathematically periodic, but the deviation is less than machine precision. We specify

waterfall(x, t(1:5:end), U(:, 1:5:end)')
view(-13, 65)
xlabel('x'), ylabel('t'), zlabel('u(x,t)')
title('Advection equation')
An animation shows the solution nicely. The bump moves with speed 2 to the right, reentering on the left as it exits to the right because of the periodic conditions.
The following are parameters and a function relevant to defining the problem.
Here we create a discretization on

children.html: m=800m=800m=800

children.value: resulting from the method of lines.
Our first initial condition has moderate density with a small bump. Because of the diffusion present, we use a stiff solver for the

clf
for plot_idx = 1:20:101
    str = sprintf("t = %.2f", t(plot_idx));
    plot(x, RHO(:, plot_idx), displayname=str)
    hold on
end
xlabel('x'),  ylabel('car density')
title('Traffic flow') 
legend(location="northwest")
The bump slowly moves backward on the roadway, spreading out and gradually fading away due to the presence of diffusion.
Now we use an initial condition with a larger bump. Note that the scale on the

children.html: yyy

children.value: -axis is much different for this solution.

clf
for plot_idx = 1:16:81
    str = sprintf("t = %.2f", t(plot_idx));
    plot(x, RHO(:, plot_idx), displayname=str)
    hold on
end
xlabel('x'),  ylabel('car density')
title('Traffic jam') 
legend(location="northwest")

In this case the density bump travels backward along the road. It also steepens on the side facing the incoming traffic and decreases much more slowly on the other side. A motorist would experience this as an abrupt increase in density, followed by a much more gradual decrease in density and resulting gradual increase in speed. (You also see some transient, high-frequency oscillations. These are caused by instabilities, as we discuss in simpler situations later in this chapter.)

clf
t = linspace(0, 2, 81);
contour(x, t, u(t)', 12)
xlabel('x'),  ylabel('t')
title('Linear advection')
In the space-time plot above, you can see the initial hump traveling rightward at constant speed. It fully traverses the domain once for each integer multiple of

children.html: t=1/2t=1/2t=1/2
hhh

children.value: ), then the CFL condition suggests that the time step should be cut by a factor of 2 also.

c=−1c=-1c=−1

children.value: , the right boundary is in the upwind/inflow direction. Thus a well-posed boundary condition is

children.html: u(1,t)=0u(1,t)=0u(1,t)=0
u(xm,t)=0u(x_m,t)=0u(xm​,t)=0

children.html: xmx_mxm​

children.value: Now we solve for an initial condition that has a single hump.

t = linspace(0, 1, 81);
clf,  contour(x, t, u(t)', 0.15:0.2:1)
xlabel x,  ylabel t
title('Advection with inflow BC')
We find that the hump gracefully exits out the downwind end.

children.html: u(1,t)=0u(1,t)=0u(1,t)=0

children.value: we were to try to impose the downwind condition

children.html: u(0,t)=0u(0,t)=0u(0,t)=0

children.value: , we only need to change the index of the interior nodes and where to append the zero value.

contour(x, t, u(t)', 0.15:0.2:1)
xlabel x,  ylabel t
title('Advection with outflow BC')
This time, the solution blows up as soon as the hump runs into the boundary because there are conflicting demands there.

children.html: c=1c=1c=1

children.value: Let’s choose a time step of

children.html: τ=0.1\tau=0.1τ=0.1

children.value: and compare to the stability regions of the Euler and backward Euler time steppers (shown as shaded regions):

zc = exp( 1i * linspace(0,2*pi,361)' );    % points on |z|=1
z = zc - 1;    % shift circle left by 1
clf,  fill(real(z), imag(z), [.8, .8, 1])
hold on,  scatter(real(0.1*lambda), imag(0.1*lambda))
axis equal,  axis square
axis([-5, 5, -5, 5]),  grid on
title('Euler')
In the Euler case it’s clear that

children.html: τ>0\tau>0τ>0
ζ\zetaζ

children.value: values fit within the stability region. Any method whose stability region includes none of the imaginary axis is an unsuitable choice for advection.

clf,  fill([-6, 6, 6, -6],[-6, -6, 6, 6], [.8, .8, 1])
z = zc + 1;   % shift circle right by 1
hold on,  scatter(real(0.1*lambda), imag(0.1*lambda))
fill(real(z), imag(z), 'w')
axis equal,  axis square
axis([-5 5 -5 5]),  grid on
title('backward Euler')
The A-stable backward Euler time stepping tells the exact opposite story: it will be absolutely stable for any choice of the time step

children.html: τ\tauτ

children.value: The eigenvalues of advection-diffusion are near-imaginary for

children.html: ϵ≈0\epsilon\approx 0ϵ≈0

children.value: and get closer to the negative real axis as

children.html: ϵ\epsilonϵ

children.value:
[x, Dx, Dxx] = diffper(40, [0, 1]);
clf
for ep = [0.001 0.01 0.05]
  lambda = eig(-Dx + ep*Dxx);
  str = sprintf("\\epsilon = %.3f", ep);
  scatter(real(lambda), imag(lambda), displayname=str)
  hold on
end
axis equal,  grid on
legend(location='northwest')
title('Eigenvalues for advection-diffusion')
Deleting the last row and column places all the eigenvalues of the discretization into the left half of the complex plane.

clf
scatter(real(lambda), imag(lambda))
axis equal,  grid on 
title('Eigenvalues of advection with zero inflow')
Note that the rightmost eigenvalues have real part at most
Consequently all solutions decay exponentially to zero as

children.html: t→∞t\to\inftyt→∞

children.value: . This matches our observation of the solution: eventually, everything flows out of the domain.

children.html: uuu

children.value: are given to be zero, so they are not unknowns in the
s. Instead they are added or removed as necessary.
The following function computes the time derivative of the system at interior points.
Our initial condition is a single hump for

children.html: uuu

children.value: Because the wave equation is hyperbolic, we can use a nonstiff explicit solver.
We plot the results for the original

children.html: uuu

children.value: variable only. Its interior values are at indices

children.html: w\mathbf{w}w

children.value: The original hump breaks into two pieces of different amplitudes, each traveling with speed

children.html: c=2c=2c=2

children.value: . They pass through one another without interference. When a hump encounters a boundary, it is perfectly reflected, but with inverted shape. At time

children.html: t=2t=2t=2

children.value: , the solution looks just like the initial condition.
We now use a wave speed that is discontinuous at

children.html: x=0x=0x=0

children.value:
clf,  contour(x, t, U', 24, linewidth=2)
colormap(cmap),  clim([-1, 1])
xlabel x,  ylabel t
title("Wave equation with variable speed")
Each pass through the interface at

children.html: x=0x=0x=0

children.value: generates a reflected and transmitted wave. By conservation of energy, these are both smaller in amplitude than the incoming bump.
